sub_section_analysis.refined_text: In some cases this becomes interesting from the academic view of learning about reaction mechanisms and in some cases practical synthetic procedures result. The study of carbocation intermediates involves learning about the factors that influence the stability (or instability) of the intermediate. Fluorne atoms more remote from the cationic center, especially in the beta position are very destabilizing.Thus fluorine atoms destabilze the tripheny cation system and slow the solvolysis of benzylic tosylates as shown below. The 6 non-bonding electrons on the F are in 2p orbitals that are of the correct size to overlap with the 2p cationic site. Fluorine atoms beta to a carbocation center are strongly destabilizing and simple beta fluoroalkyl carbocations are unknown.

But, many carbocation reactions with chiral substrates give products that show some of inversion of configureation and sometimes retention of configuration during the process. Bently and Schleyer in 1972 founded a method to determine the nucleoplicity (N) of a solvent. The ion pairs require different stereochemical outsomes depending on the reaction condition, and many SN1 reactions occur from the ion pairs before the free ion is formed. The N for several solvents is listed: CF3COOH (-5.6), HCOOH (-3.0), H2O (- .41), 20%EtOH ( -.09). The example shows a secondary substrate with R configuration giving a planar carbocation that is attacked by the solvent to give the R and S product mixture (after loss of a proton).

The study of organic chemistry, although complex, is very interesting, and begins here with an introduction of the theory of chemical bonding. The results for the first two energy levels (shells 1 and 2) are the most important for bonding in organic chemistry. 1.2 The Chemical Bond 1.2a Atomic Theory The atomic theory of electrons began in the early 1900s and gained acceptance around 1926 after Heisenberg and Schroedinger found mathematical solutions to the electronic energy levels found in atoms, the field is now called quantum mechanics. The vast information available today means that for new students of organic chemistry a great deal of study is required. The energy levels are called shells, and within these shells are other energy levels, called subshells or orbitals., that contain up to two electrons.

Understanding about the structures of organic chemistry began with a theory of bonding called valence theory (Kekule, Couper, 1858). CHAPTER 1 INTRODUCTION TO ORGANIC CHEMISTRY 1.1 Historical Background of Organic Chemistry Organic chemistry is the area of chemistry that involves the study of carbon and its compounds. In theory (Oparin, 1923) organic chemistry may have its beginnings with the big bang when the components of ammonia, nitrogen, carbon dioxide and methane combined to form amino acids, an experiment that has been verified in the laboratory (Miller, 1950). His discovery meant that the natural "vital force" was not required to synthesis organic compounds, and paved the way for many chemists to synthesize organic compounds. In the 16th century organic compounds were isolated from nature in the pure state (Scheele, 1769) and analytical methods were developed for determination of elemental composition (Lavoisier, 1784).

The body is capable of synthesizing many very complicated structures that are required for various life processes. The reactions are summarized below, and details about the reactions and mechanisms are given later. These reactions also fall into two categories: reactions that break both bonds of the alkene, and reactions that break only one bond of the alkene. Oxidation of Alkenes The double bond of alkenes is oxidized by a number of convenient reagents in synthetically useful processes. But for our purpose the biochemical marvel of converting a small molecule of mevalonate into a large poly-alkene called squalene can be appreciated.

Chemical reactions of this type are extremely important for the synthesis of new compounds and for understanding the mechanisms in organic chemistry . The conditions of the reaction, especially solvent and temperature, are also important contributors to the process. In order to understand the products of the reaction and how they are formed, the reaction is studied from a mechanistic point of view. All nucleophilic substitution reactions may take several reaction courses, but all have similar appearances at the outset. Aliphatic Nucleophilic Substitution conditions Nu + products L Nucleophile substrate (Leaving group,L) Nucleophiles are chemical species that react with centers of positive ionic character.

Synthetic Applications of Enolates Processes in organic chemistry used for synthesis generaly include functional group changes and formation of new carbon-carbon bonds. Thus carbanions participate in 1) SN2 alkylation reactions, 2) in 1,2 additions to carbonyl functions, and 3) in 1,4-additions such as Michael Reactions. This process is a very important synthetic procedure and is known as the Aldol Condensation. Enolate Reactions with Carbonyl Groups Aldol Condensation An aldehyde or ketone that has a hydrogen next to the carbonyl group, an a- hydrogen, can form an enolate in basic solution, and the enolate can react by nucleophilic addition at the carbonyl group of another molecule. Fluorine backbonding would be just the opposite in donating electrons to the carbanion center, and thus be destabilizing.

The Grignard reagent (RMgX), organo lithium reagents and organozinc reagents are used as nucleophiles in the addition to carbonyl groups , in SN2 reaction and in Michael reactions. But the overall goal is to improve mankind through the development of new and better processes to be applied in medicine, agriculture and biomedical science, that is to make life better. Then the study progresses to more complicated three-dimensional structures and finally to the investigation of reactions of organic molecules. As you proceed through organic chemistry you will write many different structures, and the writing gets easier with practice. 12 Ch 1 Introduction Hydrogen bonding in Water H H H O O H In organic compounds hydrogen bonding is very important for describing the boiling and solubility characteristics of alcohols and acids, and the concept will be given in more detail in chapters dealing with those types of molecules. We use the theories of bonding and the facts about acidic or basic properties of the molecules to understand the overall picture of what is happening.

Although configurational isomers can be difficult to visualize and understand, they are extremely important especially in biological chemistry. Also, the drug L-DOPA (L- dopamine) used for treatment of Parkinson's disease is effective only as the L or R isomer in the treatment. For example, the pain reliever Ibuprofen exists as configurational isomers but only one isomer is effective (the S isomer) in treating pain. Configurational isomers have as their only difference the way they are oriented in space, their three-dimensional arrangement. Configurational Isomers-Chirality Another type of isomerization occurs when a carbon atom is bound to four different substituents.

The study of the SN1 process centers around the chemistry of carbocations and factors that influence their stability. Substitution Nucleophilic First-order (SN1) Another reaction of organic substrates with leaving groups is a first-order reaction. In this process the leaving group departs because of the substrate structure and its interaction with the solvent to form an intermediate called a carbocation. Most solvents are polar to interact with the ionic leaving group and to stabilize the polar carbocation intermediate. This leaves out methyl and primary substrates as their cations are just too high energy, unless there is some adjacent stabilizing group (such as phenyl or CH3O).

Electrophilic Addition An important class of reaction with alkenes involves addition of an electrophile to the double bond in a process called electrophilic addition . Later, many reactions will be observed to produce alkenes on the basis of the stability of the alkene. The electrophile (E+) reacts with the alkene to produce a positively charged intermediate called a carbocation. That means that an alkene with four alkyl groups attached to the alkene is more stable than one with four hydrogens attached. 2.2 Alkenes 31 Heats of Hydrogenation Alkene D H kcal/mole CH =CH 33 2 2 CH CH=CH 30 3 2 cis 29 CH CH=CHCH 3 3 trans 28 CH C=CHCH 3 3 26 CH 3 A very important general trend in the stabilities of alkenes is found in these observations.

The reactions shown below all have very different reaction mechanisms that will be be discussed in detail in later chapters. 2.2 Alkenes 29 2.2d Physical properties of alkenes Alkenes, like alkanes, are non-polar materials with generally lower boiling points than the corresponding alkane. The Wittig reaction, which involves an aldehyde or ketone with an organophosphorus reagent is an extremely important alkene producing reaction. Dehydration (loss of H2O) and dehydrohalogenation (loss of H and halogen) are two common elimination procedures for the preparation of alkenes. Enamines will react with a,b-unsaturated carbonyl systems in the Michael reaction in method that permits introduction of new carbon-carbon bonds adjacent to the carbonyl group. The enolate adds in the 1,4 fashion to give a unit extended by three carbon atoms in a process known as the Michael reaction. Examples of the Michael reaction using methyl vinyl ketone and acrylonitrile, two common units in the reaction, are shown below. The on-sight recognition of functional groups is required for an adequate study of organic chemistry. The electronic configuration of elements is seen as combination of electrons in specific energy levels called shells that further contain energy levels known as subshells with s, p, d and f orbitals. The discovery of a laboratory synthesis of urea by Frederich Wöhler (1828) showed that organic chemicals did not have to be prepared by the vital forces of nature but could also be prepared by humans, thus opening the way for the field of synthetic organic chemistry. When a system has a basicity constant higher that the pKa of an acid then a reaction will occur to form a carbanion. Very strong bases cannot be formed in protic solvents because they abstract a hydrogen atom from the solvent to form a hydrocarbon. Although primary cations are not formed in solvolysis reactions, neighboring groups can assist the solvolysis of a primary substrate in a synchronous step to form a stable carbocation. the non bonding electrons of the carbonyl group assist the formation of the developing charge, and again the assistance is much better from the backside of the leaving group. The methyl group assists the formation of a charge in a cyclic ion to give the more stable tertiary carbocation. Rearrangement occurs in beta pheny substrates because the phenyl group donates electrons, from the backside, to give a stable cyclic phenonium ion. Optical rotation is an inherent property of an optically active compounds and is used as a physical constant for characterization of the compound. Optical rotation depends on the arrangement of atoms or groups around the chiral center—the configuration. (compound 1) S-isomer reacts with S-reagent to yield a compound with S and S centers (Compound 2) Compounds 1 and 2 are stereoisomers but they are not enantiomers, these are diastereomers. The carbon atoms are called stereogenic centers or chiral centers.A naming system has been devised so that we can distinguish one enantiomer from the other based on the An equal mixture of enantiomers will not show optical activity because half of the molecules would rotate light to the left while the other half would rotate the light to the right with a net rotation of zero.
